Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Disability Diversity and Inclusion in the Workplace

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation project will analyze the origins and impacts of large employers' efforts to promote disability diversity and inclusion ("D&I") in the workplace, and how such efforts transform the workplace as a place. Disability D&I initiatives have grown in both the public and private sectors since the passage of the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) in 1990 and even more so since the ADA Amendments Act (ADAAA) in 2008. The federal government, which employs about 2.2 million people, has set the goal of having 12% of its workforce be people with disabilities. The government has also set a 7% goal for federal contractors, a sector that includes large employers in areas such as defense, security, finance and accounting, information technology, and consulting. This study will examine why and how public and private employers have sought to hire more employees with disabilities and how and in what ways the greater presence of people with disabilities transforms workplace culture. Enhanced understanding of disability inclusion at work will provide specific and actionable information for employers and policy-makers. It will forward both national prosperity and welfare because the disability employment gap represents a loss of wealth in terms of untapped talent. The researchers will provide policy-makers and organizational leaders with specific practices they can apply.

The trends in disability D&I offer an opportunity for investigating how processes of inclusion and exclusion shape places, especially workplaces. Data gathered through interviews, observation in the form of job shadowing, and document research, will address three questions: (1) How does disability inclusion transform everyday socio-spatial relations, both in advance and because of D&I initiatives? (2) How does knowledge about disability D&I shape inclusion practices? (3) How do disability D&I narratives reconfigure ideas about disability "value?" Data collection will be focused in Washington, D.C., a significant center for the production and distribution of disability employment and equal employment policy and the hub for civilian employees of the US federal government and federal contractors, who are leading disability D&I efforts in mainstream workplaces. The analysis and findings will advance research in human geography, related disciplines, and the science of broadening participation, about the relationship between employment segregation, ideas about value, and how processes of exclusion and inclusion shape workplace character and use.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many organizations make promises about "Diversity & Inclusion" (D&I). If you live in the United States, these organizations include the companies that supply key goods and services to your hospitals, schools, and military, the companies that run your preferred web search engine, deliver packages to your door, and are otherwise part of your everyday life, as well as the U.S. federal government itself. Many of these organizations also have committed to hiring people with disabilities and to disability D&I. Disability diversity and inclusion is important because only 36% of working-age people with disabilities are employed, in contrast to 77% of those without disabilities. Moreover, even when people with disabilities are part of the workforce, they face many barriers to inclusion.

My research set out to understand disability inclusion initiatives in the professional workplaces of federal agencies and large private companies. The federal government hired 100,000 new employees with disabilities between 2010 and 2015. The nonprofits Disability:IN and the American Association of People with Disabilities (AAPD) run an annual "Disability Equality Index" (DEI) to help private companies measure their progress and honor leading companies. In 2015, 43 companies participated, and by 2019, 156 companies participated.

Within this context, I wanted to understand how disability inclusion initiatives work and if they have changed everyday life at work for people with disabilities. As my research unfolded, I found it useful to consider disability inclusion at three levels: in the everyday workplace, in the labor market, and in terms of organizations? activities away from their management centers. I conducted formal and informal interviews, participant observation, and document collection and analysis in order to investigate the world of disability D&I.

First, I found that as a result of commitments to disability inclusion, subtle but meaningful socio-spatial change has occurred to everyday workplaces as places. Because organizations want to recruit and hire more employees with disabilities, and also encourage self-identification and retention for current employees, they have made changes to the sensory characteristics, infrastructures, and locations of workplaces. The increased presence of people with disabilities and their willingness to advocate for their needs has also contributed to place change. Yet because infrastructures and habits are hard to change, workplaces also continue to contribute toward experiences of exclusion. My research contributes to understanding place as multi-sensory and therefore, that inclusion necessitates transforming places along multiple dimensions. In terms of broader impacts, my research explains why and how employers will need to commit to transforming the places where people work, if they are serious about disability inclusion.

Second, I found that although new federal policies require that agencies and contractors actively recruit people with disabilities in the labor market, these same organizations focus on the "business case" for disability inclusion rather than on the law. The business case includes claims that disability diversity enhances innovation and productivity, that disabled people are an untapped talent pool, and that people with disabilities offer a unique value proposition. My data and analysis show that while the business case is popular, it also may have unintended negative consequences. For example, the business case creates what scholars call "differential inclusion" such that only people with disabilities with a set of ideal characteristics are able to access equal employment opportunities. My research contributes to understanding how labor market dynamics shape identity categories. In terms of broader impacts, my research explains why disability inclusion stakeholders may want to exercise caution with the business case for inclusion.

Third, I found that many organizations that lead the way in terms of achieving disability D&I within their own organizations and in the business community contribute to the production of impairment and disablement elsewhere. That is, the "disability inclusion" that these organizations commit to does not extend to all of their activities. Disability D&I leaders, for example, manufacture and use weaponry intended to kill and maim, provide and use technology essential for immigration enforcement policies demonstrated to harm targets, and sell products that create conditions of impairment and disability. My research contributes to understanding how and why the growth of disability participation in mainstream professional settings in the U.S. is directly linked to disability injustice elsewhere. In terms of broader impacts, my research explains why recruiters may wish to investigate the attitudes prospective pools of employees hold toward specific business activities.

By analyzing these three different levels of disability inclusion - the everyday workplace, the labor market, and organizations' activities outside of their management centers - I also developed a new framework for understanding projects of inclusion. The framework explains inclusion projects as comprised of a who (the subjects of inclusion), a where (the places where inclusion is carried out), and an extent (the scope of the intervention or study). Forthcoming publications will develop this framework for scholars and practitioners interested in inclusion, disability, and their intersections.
